A professional soccer player came with a history of trauma on the lateral aspect of the left knee. On examination, there is a reduced range of movements and there is a swelling on the medial aspect of the left knee.

The most likely diagnosis is
disc:
Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL) injury is the most common athletic knee injury. It usually results in a lateral blow to the knee. It may occur in isolation or together with a meniscal or anterior cruciate ligament injury.

Grade I - minor and stable
Grade II - partial tear with some degree of instability
Grade III - complete tear with gross instability

On examination, there may be swelling, bruising, or deformity. Special tests include anterior and posterior drawer, Lachman, and valgus/varus stress.

Diagnosis can be confirmed with MRI.

For isolated MCL injury, the management is often conservative. Gross instability and failure of conservative measures warrant reconstructive surgery.
